description: From a corruption of of kin, from Middle English of kyn (“related, of kin”), equivalent to a- +‎ kin (1550s). Compare Old English cyn, cynn (“akin, proper, suitable”, adj.).

adjectives.description: akin (comparative more akin, superlative most akin)

entries.meaning: (of persons) Of the same kin; related by blood.
examples: The faces changed, passing in rotation. Youthful faces, bearded faces, dark faces: faces serene, or faces moody, but all akin with the brotherhood of the sea.

entries.meaning: (often followed by to) Allied by nature; similar; partaking of the same properties; of the same kind.
examples: Is not then Fruition near akin to Love?
